Name: Adolescent Health Risk Behavior Study
Funding: Original: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health & Human Development (NICHD): R01HD075806 (link: https://reporter.nih.gov/search/swrPst4q102PBv6DQWLsIA/project-details/9497809), D.P. Keating, Principal Investigator)
Upload/preprocessing: National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA): F32DA055334 (link: https://reporter.nih.gov/project-details/10525501)
ReferencesAndLinks: Multiverse Reliability: Demidenko, M. I., Mumford, J. A., & Poldrack, R. A. (2023). Test-Retest Reliability in Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging: Impact of Analytical Decisions on Individual and Group Estimates in the Monetary Incentive Delay Task. In principle acceptance of Version 3 by Peer Community in Registered Reports. https://osf.io/nqgeh

See Chapter Two in for extended description of sample: Demidenko, M. (2022). Neural Characteristics of Reward in Adolescents: Neural Substrates of Risk-taking, Researcher Degrees of Freedom and a Person-Specific Network Approach [Thesis]. https://doi.org/10.7302/4773

Demidenko, M. I., Weigard, A. S., Ganesan, K., Jang, H., Jahn, A., Huntley, E. D., & Keating, D. P. (2021). Interactions between methodological and interindividual variability: How Monetary Incentive Delay (MID) task contrast maps vary and impact associations with behavior. Brain and Behavior, 11(5), e02093. https://doi.org/10.1002/brb3.2093
OpenNeuroIncludedOutputs: task describe - json and png describing task variables
Acknowledgements: Demidenko, M. I., Mumford, J. A., & Poldrack, R. A. (2024). Impact of analytic decisions on test-retest reliability of individual and group estimates in functional magnetic resonance imaging: A multiverse analysis using the monetary incentive delay task (p. 2024.03.19.585755). bioRxiv. https://doi.org/10.1101/2024.03.19.585755
